segment.source: Signing a Driver for Public Release
segment.target: Signing a Driver for Public Release

segment.source: Before you release a driver package to the public, we recommend that you submit the package for certification.
segment.target: Before you release a driver package to the public, we recommend that you submit the package for certification.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows Hardware Certification and Hardware Dashboard Services.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows Hardware Certification and Hardware Dashboard Services.

segment.source: To submit a driver package for certification, you must sign the package with a certificate that you obtain from a trusted certification authority like VeriSign.
segment.target: To submit a driver package for certification, you must sign the package with a certificate that you obtain from a trusted certification authority like VeriSign.

segment.source: For more information, see Get a VeriSign Certificate.
segment.target: For more information, see Get a VeriSign Certificate.

segment.source: You will also need a cross certificate, which is provided by Microsoft.
segment.target: You will also need a cross certificate, which is provided by Microsoft.

segment.source: Suppose you have obtained a pair of files from Verisign: a private key file (PVK) and a software publishing certificate (SPC).
segment.target: Suppose you have obtained a pair of files from Verisign: a private key file (PVK) and a software publishing certificate (SPC).

segment.source: Also suppose you have a Microsoft Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.
segment.target: Also suppose you have a Microsoft Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.

segment.source: To sign your driver package, follow these steps.
segment.target: To sign your driver package, follow these steps.

segment.source: Use the Pvk2Pfx tool to create a Personal Information Exchange (PFX) certificate.
segment.target: Use the Pvk2Pfx tool to create a Personal Information Exchange (PFX) certificate.

segment.source: The Pvk2Pfx tool takes your PVK and SPC files as input and creates a single PFX file.
segment.target: The Pvk2Pfx tool takes your PVK and SPC files as input and creates a single PFX file.

segment.source: For this exercise, assume that your PFX file is named MyCert.pfx.
segment.target: For this exercise, assume that your PFX file is named MyCert.pfx.

segment.source: Note Once you have created your PFX file, you can reuse it for other driver projects and on other driver development computers.
segment.target: Note Once you have created your PFX file, you can reuse it for other driver projects and on other driver development computers.

segment.source: To determine which cross certificate you need, see Cross-Certificates for Kernel Mode Code Signing.
segment.target: To determine which cross certificate you need, see Cross-Certificates for Kernel Mode Code Signing.

segment.source: Verify that the required cross certificate is in $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates, where $(BASEDIR) is the base directory of the Windows kits (for example c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\8.0\\CrossCertificates).
segment.target: Verify that the required cross certificate is in $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates, where $(BASEDIR) is the base directory of the Windows kits (for example c:\\Program Files (x86)\\Windows Kits\\8.0\\CrossCertificates).

segment.source: If the required cross certificate is not there, download the cross certificate from Microsoft, and copy it to $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates.
segment.target: If the required cross certificate is not there, download the cross certificate from Microsoft, and copy it to $(BASEDIR)\\CrossCertificates.

segment.source: In Visual Studio, open the solution that contains the MyDriver and MyDriver Package projects.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, open the solution that contains the MyDriver and MyDriver Package projects.

segment.source: If the Solution Explorer window is not already open, choose Solution Explorer from the View menu.
segment.target: If the Solution Explorer window is not already open, choose Solution Explorer from the View menu.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click the package project, MyDriver Package, and choose Properties.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click the package project, MyDriver Package, and choose Properties.

segment.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.
segment.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.

segment.source: In the Sign Mode drop-down list, select Production Sign.
segment.target: In the Sign Mode drop-down list, select Production Sign.

segment.source: For Production Certificate, do one of the following:
segment.target: For Production Certificate, do one of the following:

segment.source: Enter the path to your signing certificate (for example c:\\Certs\\MyCert.pfx).
segment.target: Enter the path to your signing certificate (for example c:\\Certs\\MyCert.pfx).

segment.source: Choose Select From File, and browse to your signing certificate.
segment.target: Choose Select From File, and browse to your signing certificate.

segment.source: Choose Select From Store and choose a certificate that you previously imported into a certificate store.
segment.target: Choose Select From Store and choose a certificate that you previously imported into a certificate store.

segment.source: Note To import a certificate into a store, right-click the certificate file (PFX file), and choose Install PFX.
segment.target: Note To import a certificate into a store, right-click the certificate file (PFX file), and choose Install PFX.

segment.source: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Import Wizard.
segment.target: Follow the instructions in the Certificate Import Wizard.

segment.source: Note If you decide to use a different certificate at a later time, be sure that your new certificate gets imported into the certificate store.
segment.target: Note If you decide to use a different certificate at a later time, be sure that your new certificate gets imported into the certificate store.

segment.source: If you choose Select From File and browse to your new certificate, the new certificate will be automatically imported into the certificate store.
segment.target: If you choose Select From File and browse to your new certificate, the new certificate will be automatically imported into the certificate store.

segment.source: However, if you manually enter the path to your new certificate, it will not be automatically imported into the certificate store.
segment.target: However, if you manually enter the path to your new certificate, it will not be automatically imported into the certificate store.

segment.source: In that case, you must right-click your new certificate file and choose Install PFX.
segment.target: In that case, you must right-click your new certificate file and choose Install PFX.

segment.source: On the Driver Signing General property page, for TimeStampServer, select one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list.
segment.target: On the Driver Signing General property page, for TimeStampServer, select one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list.

segment.source: Note Using one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list requires that you be connected to the Internet when you build your driver package.
segment.target: Note Using one of the time stamp servers in the drop-down list requires that you be connected to the Internet when you build your driver package.

segment.source: If you need to be disconnected from the Internet when you build your driver package, clear the TimeStampServer field.
segment.target: If you need to be disconnected from the Internet when you build your driver package, clear the TimeStampServer field.

segment.source: In the property pages for the package, navigate to Configuration Properties Inf2Cat General.
segment.target: In the property pages for the package, navigate to Configuration Properties Inf2Cat General.

segment.source: In the Run Inf2Cat drop-down list, select Yes.
segment.target: In the Run Inf2Cat drop-down list, select Yes.

segment.source: Close the property pages for the package.
segment.target: Close the property pages for the package.

segment.source: Right-click the driver project, MyDriver, and choose Properties
segment.target: Right-click the driver project, MyDriver, and choose Properties

segment.source: In the property pages for the driver, navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.
segment.target: In the property pages for the driver, navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.

segment.source: Set TimeStampServer to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.
segment.target: Set TimeStampServer to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.

segment.source: Set Sign Mode to Production Sign, and set Production Certificate to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.
segment.target: Set Sign Mode to Production Sign, and set Production Certificate to the same value that you used in the driver package properties.

segment.source: When you are ready to build your driver package, press F5.
segment.target: When you are ready to build your driver package, press F5.

segment.source: Visual Studio will automatically sign your package and your driver file.
segment.target: Visual Studio will automatically sign your package and your driver file.

segment.source: If you have configured deployment, Visual Studio will also deploy your signed driver package to a test computer.
segment.target: If you have configured deployment, Visual Studio will also deploy your signed driver package to a test computer.

segment.source: For more information, see Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1).
segment.target: For more information, see Provision a computer for driver deployment and testing (WDK 8.1).

segment.source: Viewing the driver package files
segment.target: Viewing the driver package files

segment.source: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.
segment.target: After you build your solution, navigate in File Explorer to the folder that contains your driver package.

segment.source: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.
segment.target: One of the files in the package is a catalog file.

segment.source: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.
segment.target: The catalog file contains the digital signature for the package.

segment.source: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see Writing a KMDF driver based on a template.
segment.target: For an example of viewing the files in a signed package, see Writing a KMDF driver based on a template.

segment.source: Getting a WHQL release signature
segment.target: Getting a WHQL release signature

segment.source: When your driver package passes the certification tests, it can be signed by Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL).
segment.target: When your driver package passes the certification tests, it can be signed by Windows Hardware Quality Labs (WHQL).

segment.source: If your driver package is signed by WHQL, it can be distributed through the Windows Update program or other Microsoft-supported distribution mechanisms.
segment.target: If your driver package is signed by WHQL, it can be distributed through the Windows Update program or other Microsoft-supported distribution mechanisms.

segment.source: Signing a package compared to signing an individual driver file
segment.target: Signing a package compared to signing an individual driver file

segment.source: A driver package contains several files.
segment.target: A driver package contains several files.

segment.source: Typically a driver package has one or more driver files, an information file (INF file), and a catalog file.
segment.target: Typically a driver package has one or more driver files, an information file (INF file), and a catalog file.

segment.source: The catalog file contains information about the other files in the package.
segment.target: The catalog file contains information about the other files in the package.

segment.source: When you sign the catalog file, the signature in the catalog file serves as the signature for the entire driver package.
segment.target: When you sign the catalog file, the signature in the catalog file serves as the signature for the entire driver package.

segment.source: In other words, signing the catalog file is the same as signing the driver package.
segment.target: In other words, signing the catalog file is the same as signing the driver package.

segment.source: In most cases, it is sufficient to sign the driver package, and it is not necessary to sign individual driver files.
segment.target: In most cases, it is sufficient to sign the driver package, and it is not necessary to sign individual driver files.

segment.source: Sometimes, however, you need to sign both the package and the individual driver files.
segment.target: Sometimes, however, you need to sign both the package and the individual driver files.

segment.source: For example, boot-start driver files must be individually signed.
segment.target: For example, boot-start driver files must be individually signed.

segment.source: Signing an individual driver file is referred to as embedding a signature in the driver file.
segment.target: Signing an individual driver file is referred to as embedding a signature in the driver file.

segment.source: Suppose you have a Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.
segment.target: Suppose you have a Visual Studio solution that contains a driver project named MyDriver and a driver package project named MyDriver Package.

segment.source: Visual Studio provides two sets of property pages: one for My Driver and one for My Driver Package.
segment.target: Visual Studio provides two sets of property pages: one for My Driver and one for My Driver Package.

segment.source: To sign the driver package, set the Driver Signing properties of My Driver Package.
segment.target: To sign the driver package, set the Driver Signing properties of My Driver Package.

segment.source: To embed a signature in the individual driver file, set the Driver Signing properties of My Driver.
segment.target: To embed a signature in the individual driver file, set the Driver Signing properties of My Driver.

segment.source: When you set the driver package properties for production signing, remember to adjust the signing properties of the individual driver files accordingly.
segment.target: When you set the driver package properties for production signing, remember to adjust the signing properties of the individual driver files accordingly.

segment.source: Either turn off signing for the individual driver files, or set the individual driver files to use the same certificate that you specified for the package.
segment.target: Either turn off signing for the individual driver files, or set the individual driver files to use the same certificate that you specified for the package.

segment.source: Signing a driver package with two signatures
segment.target: Signing a driver package with two signatures

segment.source: In some cases, you might want to sign a driver package with two different signatures.
segment.target: In some cases, you might want to sign a driver package with two different signatures.

segment.source: For example, suppose you want your driver to run on Windows Vista and Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10.
segment.target: For example, suppose you want your driver to run on Windows Vista and Windows 7, 8, 8.1, and 10.

segment.source: Windows Vista supports only SHA1 signatures, but the later versions of Windows also support SHA2.
segment.target: Windows Vista supports only SHA1 signatures, but the later versions of Windows also support SHA2.

segment.source: Note SHA1 deprecation does not apply to drivers.
segment.target: Note SHA1 deprecation does not apply to drivers.

segment.source: For info about the end of SHA1 support in Windows, see Windows Enforcement of Authenticode Code Signing and Timestamping.
segment.target: For info about the end of SHA1 support in Windows, see Windows Enforcement of Authenticode Code Signing and Timestamping.

segment.source: You can sign your driver package with a primary signature that uses SHA1.
segment.target: You can sign your driver package with a primary signature that uses SHA1.

segment.source: Then you can append a secondary signature that uses SHA256.
segment.target: Then you can append a secondary signature that uses SHA256.

segment.source: You can use the same certificate for both signatures, or you can use separate certificates.
segment.target: You can use the same certificate for both signatures, or you can use separate certificates.

segment.source: Here are the steps to create the two signatures using Visual Studio.
segment.target: Here are the steps to create the two signatures using Visual Studio.

segment.source: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click Solution SolutionName, and choose Configuration Manager.
segment.target: In the Solution Explorer window, right-click Solution SolutionName, and choose Configuration Manager.

segment.source: For the driver project and the package project, set Configuration to Win7 Release, and set Platform to x64.
segment.target: For the driver project and the package project, set Configuration to Win7 Release, and set Platform to x64.

segment.source: Open the property pages for the driver package.
segment.target: Open the property pages for the driver package.

segment.source: Navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.
segment.target: Navigate to Configuration Properties Driver Signing General.

segment.source: In the Sign Mode drop-down list, select Production Sign.
segment.target: In the Sign Mode drop-down list, select Production Sign.

segment.source: For Production Certificate, enter the path to your signing certificate.
segment.target: For Production Certificate, enter the path to your signing certificate.

segment.source: In the property pages for the driver package, navigate to Configuration Properties Custom Build Step General.
segment.target: In the property pages for the driver package, navigate to Configuration Properties Custom Build Step General.

segment.source: For Description, select Performing Custom Build Step.
segment.target: For Description, select Performing Custom Build Step.

segment.source: For Execute After, select DriverProductionSign.
segment.target: For Execute After, select DriverProductionSign.

segment.source: For Command Line, enter this command.
segment.target: For Command Line, enter this command.

segment.source: where XX...XX is the hash of the certificate you are using for the the secondary signature.
segment.target: where XX...XX is the hash of the certificate you are using for the the secondary signature.

segment.source: Note To see the hash (also called the thumb print) of a certificate, open a Command Prompt window and navigate to the directory that contains your certificate.
segment.target: Note To see the hash (also called the thumb print) of a certificate, open a Command Prompt window and navigate to the directory that contains your certificate.

segment.source: Enter the command certutil -dump CertName.pfx, where CertName.pfx is the name of your certificate.
segment.target: Enter the command certutil -dump CertName.pfx, where CertName.pfx is the name of your certificate.
